Award.AwardTitle: Cityscape Genomics of Rats in New York City
Award.AbstractNarration:
Brown rats (also known as Norway or sewer rats) are one of the most common mammals in the world, and cause significant damage to human health and infrastructure. Cities in particular harbor very large rat populations, but their biology is poorly known. This study will address novel and important questions about the evolutionary and ecological processes occurring in the built environment using the infamous rat population in New York City. What specific types of urban infrastructure, such as sewers or subways, do rats use to move through the city? Are rat movements associated with socioeconomics of human neighborhoods? Where did NYC rats come from, and how are they related to other populations around the world? How have rats evolved since they invaded NYC in the 18th century? Results from this project will also be used to introduce students and the public to evolutionary biology by funding art projects and innovative curricular materials.

Several complementary genomic approaches will be used to understand the evolution of brown rats from local to global scales. First, landscape modeling based on structural and socioeconomic characteristics of NYC will shed light on the drivers of local population structure and movements of rats within NYC. Next, signatures of historical population size changes and ancestry that are encoded in the genomes of rats from around the world will then be examined. Within NYC, genes involved in recent adaptation to the urban environment will also be identified. Finally, these evolutionary changes will be confirmed using DNA extracted from museum specimens of rats collected over the last 125 years.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Brown rats (AKA Norway rats, Rattus norvegicus) are one of the most widespread and destructive invasive species around the world. Humans have introduced brown rats to nearly every terrestrial landmass around the world, but cities in particular support very large rat populations due to the concentration of food and nesting sites. In this study, we sought to understand the recent evolutionary history of rats as humans transported them around the world, as well as how rats move around, spread their genes, and potentially adapt in contemporary cities.

To understand the recent evolutionary history of rats, we worked with a global team of collaborators to collect biological samples from rats around the world. After generating DNA data from these rats, we used population genomic analyses to identify relationships between rats from different regions and the dates when they diverged. Our analyses inferred that brown rats moved from their original range in northern China into southeast Asia relatively recently (i.e., approximately 1,000 years ago), and then moved westward with human assistance, reaching central Europe within the last several centuries. Once brown rats reached Western Europe a few hundred years ago, Europeans introduced brown rats to port cities across the world, most notably in the Americas, Africa, Australia, and New Zealand. A logical conclusion is that rats became a global invasive species as a byproduct of European imperialism. Unexpectedly, rat populations on the western coast of North America exhibited genetic signatures of both rats introduced to eastern North America from western Europe, and older signatures from east Asian populations. We concluded that rats were introduced from Asian and western European populations to western North America relatively simultaneously. Most cities we analyzed were found to contain a single lineage of brown rats, indicating that cities are not constantly reinvaded once rats become established.

On the very local level, brown rats are a common denizen of cities but are not distributed equally throughout urban neighborhoods. To examine how rats move around and spread their genes in cities, we collected hundreds of rat samples from New York City, New Orleans, Vancouver, and Salvador, Brazil with an international team of collaborators. We generated genomic data from rats in these four cities and analyzed genetic relatedness of rats within each city. We also built models of the urban habitat features that we hypothesized would affect how rats move through cities and spread their genes and tested the success of these models at explaining the genetic patterns we observed. We found that waterways, roadways, and "resource deserts" where rats are prevented from accessing human food or nesting sites may disrupt connectivity between rats in urban landscapes. Our modeling efforts identified human population density, the spatial orientation of green spaces, building age and condition, and socioeconomics as factors that affect rat presence and gene flow among rat populations. We also sequenced whole genomes from NYC rats and identified several regions of the genome that may indicate local adaptation in urban rats. These regions were associated with genes involved in metabolism, diet, the nervous system, and locomotion.

This project also aimed to have broader impacts on how the human residents of NYC think about brown rats. To this end, we worked with local artists to develop public art projects broadly centered around the theme of connections between people and human rats. Additionally, the Principal Investigator and a PhD student funded by this grant worked with the NYC Department of Health & Mental Hygiene for two years to improve NYC's efforts at managing urban rat populations and the resources that humans provide to rats.
